alert.note: Alert for Taos (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued August 09 at 1:12PM MDT until August 09 at 5:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... Southern Taos County in north central New Mexico... * Until 500 PM MDT. * At 112 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 0.5 and 0.75 inches of rain are estimated to have fallen with a heavy rainfall rate of 1 to 1.5 inches in 1 hour. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. Excessive rainfall will impact the extreme Northwestern Hermits Peak-Calf Canyon wildfire burn scar and drainages feeding into the Aqua Piedra Creek, Rito Angosturara and other small creeks feeding into the upper Rio Pueblo. Any debris flows can consist of torrents of water, rock, mud, ash, burned vegetation and other loose materials. HAZARD...Thunderstorms producing heavy rainfall and potential flash flooding. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Excessive runoff over the burn scar and potentially life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Tres Ritos and the extreme Northwestern Hermits Peak-Calf Canyon wildfire burn scar. This includes the following recreation areas... Agua Piedra Campground, Comales Campground, Duran Canyon Campground, Sipapu Ski Area and Flechado Picnic Area. This includes the following highways... State Road 518 between Mile Markers 45 and 57. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE EXPECTED RAINFALL RATE...1-1.5 INCHES IN 1 HOUR
info.instruction: Runoff from rainfall will cause elevated water levels within vulnerable drainages in and downstream of the extreme Northwestern Hermits Peak-Calf Canyon wildfire burn scar. Do not camp along streams and rivers. Remain alert when hiking in steep, narrow canyons. Know where you are relative to low spots and drainages.
